trans-unit.source: Working with Geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Working with Geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Understand how to create, index and query spatial objects with Azure DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Understand how to create, index and query spatial objects with Azure DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Working with Geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB
trans-unit.target: Working with Geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB

trans-unit.source: This article is an introduction to the geospatial functionality in [Azure DocumentDB](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/documentdb/).
trans-unit.target: This article is an introduction to the geospatial functionality in [Azure DocumentDB](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/documentdb/).

trans-unit.source: After reading this, you will be able to answer the following questions:
trans-unit.target: After reading this, you will be able to answer the following questions:

trans-unit.source: How do I store spatial data in Azure DocumentDB?
trans-unit.target: How do I store spatial data in Azure DocumentDB?

trans-unit.source: How can I query geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB in SQL and LINQ?
trans-unit.target: How can I query geospatial data in Azure DocumentDB in SQL and LINQ?

trans-unit.source: How do I enable or disable spatial indexing in DocumentDB?
trans-unit.target: How do I enable or disable spatial indexing in DocumentDB?

trans-unit.source: Please see this [Github project](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/samples/code-samples/Queries.Spatial) for code samples.
trans-unit.target: Please see this [Github project](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/samples/code-samples/Queries.Spatial) for code samples.

trans-unit.source: Introduction to Spatial data
trans-unit.target: Introduction to Spatial data

trans-unit.source: Spatial data describes the position and shape of objects in space.
trans-unit.target: Spatial data describes the position and shape of objects in space.

trans-unit.source: In most applications, these correspond to objects on the earth, i.e. geospatial data.
trans-unit.target: In most applications, these correspond to objects on the earth, i.e. geospatial data.

trans-unit.source: Spatial data can be used to represent the location of a person, a place of interest, or the boundary of a city, or a lake.
trans-unit.target: Spatial data can be used to represent the location of a person, a place of interest, or the boundary of a city, or a lake.

trans-unit.source: Common use cases often involve proximity queries, for e.g., "find all coffee shops near my current location".
trans-unit.target: Common use cases often involve proximity queries, for e.g., "find all coffee shops near my current location".

trans-unit.source: GeoJSON
trans-unit.target: GeoJSON

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports indexing and querying of geospatial data that's represented using the [GeoJSON specification](http://geojson.org/geojson-spec.html).
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports indexing and querying of geospatial data that's represented using the [GeoJSON specification](http://geojson.org/geojson-spec.html).

trans-unit.source: GeoJSON data structures are always valid JSON objects, so they can be stored and queried using DocumentDB without any specialized tools or libraries.
trans-unit.target: GeoJSON data structures are always valid JSON objects, so they can be stored and queried using DocumentDB without any specialized tools or libraries.

trans-unit.source: The DocumentDB SDKs provide helper classes and methods that make it easy to work with spatial data.
trans-unit.target: The DocumentDB SDKs provide helper classes and methods that make it easy to work with spatial data.

trans-unit.source: Points, Linestrings and Polygons
trans-unit.target: Points, Linestrings and Polygons

trans-unit.source: A **Point** denotes a single position in space.
trans-unit.target: A **Point** denotes a single position in space.

trans-unit.source: In geospatial data, a point represents the exact location, which could be a street address of a grocery store, a kiosk, an automobile or a city.
trans-unit.target: In geospatial data, a point represents the exact location, which could be a street address of a grocery store, a kiosk, an automobile or a city.

trans-unit.source: A point is represented in GeoJSON (and DocumentDB) using its coordinate pair or longitude and latitude.
trans-unit.target: A point is represented in GeoJSON (and DocumentDB) using its coordinate pair or longitude and latitude.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example JSON for a point.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example JSON for a point.

trans-unit.source: Points in DocumentDB
trans-unit.target: Points in DocumentDB

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The GeoJSON specification specifies longitude first and latitude second.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The GeoJSON specification specifies longitude first and latitude second.

trans-unit.source: Like in other mapping applications, longitude and latitude are angles and represented in terms of degrees.
trans-unit.target: Like in other mapping applications, longitude and latitude are angles and represented in terms of degrees.

trans-unit.source: Longitude values are measured from the Prime Meridian and are between -180 and 180.0 degrees, and latitude values are measured from the equator and are between -90.0 and 90.0 degrees.
trans-unit.target: Longitude values are measured from the Prime Meridian and are between -180 and 180.0 degrees, and latitude values are measured from the equator and are between -90.0 and 90.0 degrees.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB interprets coordinates as represented per the WGS-84 reference system.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB interprets coordinates as represented per the WGS-84 reference system.

trans-unit.source: Please see below for more details about coordinate reference systems.
trans-unit.target: Please see below for more details about coordinate reference systems.

trans-unit.source: This can be embedded in a DocumentDB document as shown in this example of a user profile containing location data:
trans-unit.target: This can be embedded in a DocumentDB document as shown in this example of a user profile containing location data:

trans-unit.source: Use Profile with Location stored in DocumentDB
trans-unit.target: Use Profile with Location stored in DocumentDB

trans-unit.source: In addition to points, GeoJSON also supports LineStrings and Polygons.
trans-unit.target: In addition to points, GeoJSON also supports LineStrings and Polygons.

trans-unit.source: **LineStrings** represent a series of two or more points in space and the line segments that connect them.
trans-unit.target: **LineStrings** represent a series of two or more points in space and the line segments that connect them.

trans-unit.source: In geospatial data, linestrings are commonly used to represent highways or rivers.
trans-unit.target: In geospatial data, linestrings are commonly used to represent highways or rivers.

trans-unit.source: A **polygon** is a boundary of connected points that forms a closed LineString.
trans-unit.target: A **polygon** is a boundary of connected points that forms a closed LineString.

trans-unit.source: Polygons are commonly used to represent natural formations like lakes or political jurisdictions like cities and states.
trans-unit.target: Polygons are commonly used to represent natural formations like lakes or political jurisdictions like cities and states.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of a polygon in DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of a polygon in DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Polygons in DocumentDB
trans-unit.target: Polygons in DocumentDB

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The GeoJSON specification requires that for valid polygons, the last coordinate pair provided should be the same as the first, to create a closed shape.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The GeoJSON specification requires that for valid polygons, the last coordinate pair provided should be the same as the first, to create a closed shape.

trans-unit.source: Points within a polygon must be specified in counter-clockwise order.
trans-unit.target: Points within a polygon must be specified in counter-clockwise order.

trans-unit.source: A polygon specified in clockwise order represents the inverse of the region within it.
trans-unit.target: A polygon specified in clockwise order represents the inverse of the region within it.

trans-unit.source: In addition to Point, LineString and Polygon, GeoJSON also specifies the representation for how to group multiple geospatial locations, as well as how to associate arbitrary properties with geolocation as a **Feature**.
trans-unit.target: In addition to Point, LineString and Polygon, GeoJSON also specifies the representation for how to group multiple geospatial locations, as well as how to associate arbitrary properties with geolocation as a **Feature**.

trans-unit.source: Since these objects are valid JSON, they can all be stored and processed in DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Since these objects are valid JSON, they can all be stored and processed in DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Coordinate Reference Systems
trans-unit.target: Coordinate Reference Systems

trans-unit.source: Since the shape of the earth is irregular, coordinates of geospatial data is represented in many coordinate reference systems (CRS), each with their own frames of reference and units of measurement.
trans-unit.target: Since the shape of the earth is irregular, coordinates of geospatial data is represented in many coordinate reference systems (CRS), each with their own frames of reference and units of measurement.

trans-unit.source: For example, the "National Grid of Britain" is a reference system is very accurate for the United Kingdom, but not outside it.
trans-unit.target: For example, the "National Grid of Britain" is a reference system is very accurate for the United Kingdom, but not outside it.

trans-unit.source: The most popular CRS in use today is the World Geodetic System [WGS-84](http://earth-info.nga.mil/GandG/wgs84/).
trans-unit.target: The most popular CRS in use today is the World Geodetic System [WGS-84](http://earth-info.nga.mil/GandG/wgs84/).

trans-unit.source: GPS devices, and many mapping services including Google Maps and Bing Maps APIs use WGS-84.
trans-unit.target: GPS devices, and many mapping services including Google Maps and Bing Maps APIs use WGS-84.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports indexing and querying of geospatial data using the WGS-84 CRS only.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports indexing and querying of geospatial data using the WGS-84 CRS only.

trans-unit.source: Creating Documents with spatial data
trans-unit.target: Creating Documents with spatial data

trans-unit.source: When you create documents that contain GeoJSON values, they are automatically indexed with a spatial index in accordance to the indexing policy of the collection.
trans-unit.target: When you create documents that contain GeoJSON values, they are automatically indexed with a spatial index in accordance to the indexing policy of the collection.

trans-unit.source: If you're working with a DocumentDB SDK in a dynamically typed language like Python or Node.js, you must create valid GeoJSON.
trans-unit.target: If you're working with a DocumentDB SDK in a dynamically typed language like Python or Node.js, you must create valid GeoJSON.

trans-unit.source: Create Document with Geospatial data in Node.js
trans-unit.target: Create Document with Geospatial data in Node.js

trans-unit.source: If you're working with the .NET (or Java) SDKs, you can use the new Point and Polygon classes within the Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Spatial namespace to embed location information within your application objects.
trans-unit.target: If you're working with the .NET (or Java) SDKs, you can use the new Point and Polygon classes within the Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Spatial namespace to embed location information within your application objects.

trans-unit.source: These classes help simplify the serialization and deserialization of spatial data into GeoJSON.
trans-unit.target: These classes help simplify the serialization and deserialization of spatial data into GeoJSON.

trans-unit.source: Create Document with Geospatial data in .NET
trans-unit.target: Create Document with Geospatial data in .NET

trans-unit.source: If you don't have the latitude and longitude information, but have the physical addresses or location name like city or country, you can look up the actual coordinates by using a geocoding service like Bing Maps REST Services.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have the latitude and longitude information, but have the physical addresses or location name like city or country, you can look up the actual coordinates by using a geocoding service like Bing Maps REST Services.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about Bing Maps geocoding [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff701713.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Learn more about Bing Maps geocoding [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff701713.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Querying Spatial Types
trans-unit.target: Querying Spatial Types

trans-unit.source: Now that we've taken a look at how to insert geospatial data, let's take a look at how to query this data using DocumentDB using SQL and LINQ.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've taken a look at how to insert geospatial data, let's take a look at how to query this data using DocumentDB using SQL and LINQ.

trans-unit.source: Spatial SQL Built-in functions
trans-unit.target: Spatial SQL Built-in functions

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports the following Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) built-in functions for geospatial querying.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports the following Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) built-in functions for geospatial querying.

trans-unit.source: For more details on the complete set of built-in functions in the SQL language, please refer to [Query DocumentDB](documentdb-sql-query.md).
trans-unit.target: For more details on the complete set of built-in functions in the SQL language, please refer to [Query DocumentDB](documentdb-sql-query.md).

trans-unit.source: Usage
trans-unit.target: Usage

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: ST_DISTANCE (point_expr, point_expr)
trans-unit.target: ST_DISTANCE (point_expr, point_expr)

trans-unit.source: Returns the distance between the two GeoJSON point expressions.
trans-unit.target: Returns the distance between the two GeoJSON point expressions.

trans-unit.source: ST_WITHIN (point_expr, polygon_expr)
trans-unit.target: ST_WITHIN (point_expr, polygon_expr)

trans-unit.source: Returns a Boolean expression indicating whether the GeoJSON point specified in the first argument is within the GeoJSON polygon in the second argument.
trans-unit.target: Returns a Boolean expression indicating whether the GeoJSON point specified in the first argument is within the GeoJSON polygon in the second argument.

trans-unit.source: ST_ISVALID
trans-unit.target: ST_ISVALID

trans-unit.source: Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the specified GeoJSON point or polygon expression is valid.
trans-unit.target: Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the specified GeoJSON point or polygon expression is valid.

trans-unit.source: ST_ISVALIDDETAILED
trans-unit.target: ST_ISVALIDDETAILED

trans-unit.source: Returns a JSON value containing a Boolean value if the specified GeoJSON point or polygon expression is valid, and if invalid, additionally the reason as a string value.
trans-unit.target: Returns a JSON value containing a Boolean value if the specified GeoJSON point or polygon expression is valid, and if invalid, additionally the reason as a string value.

trans-unit.source: Spatial functions can be used to perform proximity querries against spatial data.
trans-unit.target: Spatial functions can be used to perform proximity querries against spatial data.

trans-unit.source: For example, here's a query that returns all family documents that are within 30 km of the specified location using the ST_DISTANCE built-in function.
trans-unit.target: For example, here's a query that returns all family documents that are within 30 km of the specified location using the ST_DISTANCE built-in function.

trans-unit.source: Query
trans-unit.target: Query

trans-unit.source: Results
trans-unit.target: Results

trans-unit.source: If you include spatial indexing in your indexing policy, then "distance queries" will be served efficiently through the index.
trans-unit.target: If you include spatial indexing in your indexing policy, then "distance queries" will be served efficiently through the index.

trans-unit.source: For more details on spatial indexing, please see the section below.
trans-unit.target: For more details on spatial indexing, please see the section below.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have a spatial index for the specified paths, you can still perform spatial queries by specifying `x-ms-documentdb-query-enable-scan` request header with the value set to "true".
trans-unit.target: If you don't have a spatial index for the specified paths, you can still perform spatial queries by specifying `x-ms-documentdb-query-enable-scan` request header with the value set to "true".

trans-unit.source: In .NET, this can be done by passing the optional **FeedOptions** argument to queries with [EnableScanInQuery](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.feedoptions.enablescaninquery.aspx#P:Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.FeedOptions.EnableScanInQuery) set to true.
trans-unit.target: In .NET, this can be done by passing the optional **FeedOptions** argument to queries with [EnableScanInQuery](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.feedoptions.enablescaninquery.aspx#P:Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.FeedOptions.EnableScanInQuery) set to true.

trans-unit.source: ST_WITHIN can be used to check if a point lies within a polygon.
trans-unit.target: ST_WITHIN can be used to check if a point lies within a polygon.

trans-unit.source: Commonly polygons are used to represent boundaries like zip codes, state boundaries, or natural formations.
trans-unit.target: Commonly polygons are used to represent boundaries like zip codes, state boundaries, or natural formations.

trans-unit.source: Again if you include spatial indexing in your indexing policy, then "within" queries will be served efficiently through the index.
trans-unit.target: Again if you include spatial indexing in your indexing policy, then "within" queries will be served efficiently through the index.

trans-unit.source: Polygon arguments in ST_WITHIN can contain only a single ring, i.e. the polygons must not contain holes in them.
trans-unit.target: Polygon arguments in ST_WITHIN can contain only a single ring, i.e. the polygons must not contain holes in them.

trans-unit.source: Check the [DocumentDB limits](documentdb-limits.md) for the maximum number of points allowed in a polygon for an ST_WITHIN query.
trans-unit.target: Check the [DocumentDB limits](documentdb-limits.md) for the maximum number of points allowed in a polygon for an ST_WITHIN query.

trans-unit.source: Query
trans-unit.target: Query

trans-unit.source: Results
trans-unit.target: Results

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Similar to how mismatched types works in DocumentDB query, if the location value specified in either argument is malformed or invalid, then it will evaluate to **undefined** and the evaluated document to be skipped from the query results.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Similar to how mismatched types works in DocumentDB query, if the location value specified in either argument is malformed or invalid, then it will evaluate to **undefined** and the evaluated document to be skipped from the query results.

trans-unit.source: If your query returns no results, run ST_ISVALIDDETAILED To debug why the spatail type is invalid.
trans-unit.target: If your query returns no results, run ST_ISVALIDDETAILED To debug why the spatail type is invalid.

trans-unit.source: ST_ISVALID and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED can be used to check if a spatial object is valid.
trans-unit.target: ST_ISVALID and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED can be used to check if a spatial object is valid.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following query checks the validity of a point with an out of range latitude value (-132.8).
trans-unit.target: For example, the following query checks the validity of a point with an out of range latitude value (-132.8).

trans-unit.source: ST_ISVALID returns just a Boolean value, and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED returns the Boolean and a string containing the reason why it is considered invalid.
trans-unit.target: ST_ISVALID returns just a Boolean value, and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED returns the Boolean and a string containing the reason why it is considered invalid.

trans-unit.source: ** Query **
trans-unit.target: ** Query **

trans-unit.source: Results
trans-unit.target: Results

trans-unit.source: These functions can also be used to validate polygons.
trans-unit.target: These functions can also be used to validate polygons.

trans-unit.source: For example, here we use ST_ISVALIDDETAILED to validate a polygon that is not closed.
trans-unit.target: For example, here we use ST_ISVALIDDETAILED to validate a polygon that is not closed.

trans-unit.source: Query
trans-unit.target: Query

trans-unit.source: Results
trans-unit.target: Results

trans-unit.source: LINQ Querying in the .NET SDK
trans-unit.target: LINQ Querying in the .NET SDK

trans-unit.source: The DocumentDB .NET SDK also providers stub methods `Distance()` and `Within()` for use within LINQ expressions.
trans-unit.target: The DocumentDB .NET SDK also providers stub methods `Distance()` and `Within()` for use within LINQ expressions.

trans-unit.source: The DocumentDB LINQ provider translates these method calls to the equivalent SQL built-in function calls (ST_DISTANCE and ST_WITHIN respectively).
trans-unit.target: The DocumentDB LINQ provider translates these method calls to the equivalent SQL built-in function calls (ST_DISTANCE and ST_WITHIN respectively).

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of a LINQ query that finds all documents in the DocumentDB collection whose "location" value is within a radius of 30km of the specified point using LINQ.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of a LINQ query that finds all documents in the DocumentDB collection whose "location" value is within a radius of 30km of the specified point using LINQ.

trans-unit.source: LINQ query for Distance
trans-unit.target: LINQ query for Distance

trans-unit.source: Similarly, here's a query for finding all the documents whose "location" is within the specified box/polygon.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, here's a query for finding all the documents whose "location" is within the specified box/polygon.

trans-unit.source: LINQ query for Within
trans-unit.target: LINQ query for Within

trans-unit.source: Now that we've taken a look at how to query documents using LINQ and SQL, let's take a look at how to configure DocumentDB for spatial indexing.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've taken a look at how to query documents using LINQ and SQL, let's take a look at how to configure DocumentDB for spatial indexing.

trans-unit.source: Indexing
trans-unit.target: Indexing

trans-unit.source: As we described in the [Schema Agnostic Indexing with Azure DocumentDB](http://www.vldb.org/pvldb/vol8/p1668-shukla.pdf) paper, we designed DocumentDB’s database engine to be truly schema agnostic and provide first class support for JSON.
trans-unit.target: As we described in the [Schema Agnostic Indexing with Azure DocumentDB](http://www.vldb.org/pvldb/vol8/p1668-shukla.pdf) paper, we designed DocumentDB’s database engine to be truly schema agnostic and provide first class support for JSON.

trans-unit.source: The write optimized database engine of DocumentDB now also natively understands spatial data represented in the GeoJSON standard.
trans-unit.target: The write optimized database engine of DocumentDB now also natively understands spatial data represented in the GeoJSON standard.

trans-unit.source: In a nutshell, the geometry is projected from geodetic coordinates onto a 2D plane then divided progressively into cells using a **quadtree**.
trans-unit.target: In a nutshell, the geometry is projected from geodetic coordinates onto a 2D plane then divided progressively into cells using a **quadtree**.

trans-unit.source: These cells are mapped to 1D based on the location of the cell within a **Hilbert space filling curve**, which preserves locality of points.
trans-unit.target: These cells are mapped to 1D based on the location of the cell within a **Hilbert space filling curve**, which preserves locality of points.

trans-unit.source: Additionally when location data is indexed, it goes through a process known as **tessellation**, i.e. all the cells that intersect a location are identified and stored as keys in the DocumentDB index.
trans-unit.target: Additionally when location data is indexed, it goes through a process known as **tessellation**, i.e. all the cells that intersect a location are identified and stored as keys in the DocumentDB index.

trans-unit.source: At query time, arguments like points and polygons are also tessellated to extract the relevant cell ID ranges, then used to retrieve data from the index.
trans-unit.target: At query time, arguments like points and polygons are also tessellated to extract the relevant cell ID ranges, then used to retrieve data from the index.

trans-unit.source: If you specify an indexing policy that includes spatial index for /* (all paths), then all points found within the collection are indexed for efficient spatial queries (ST_WITHIN and ST_DISTANCE).
trans-unit.target: If you specify an indexing policy that includes spatial index for /* (all paths), then all points found within the collection are indexed for efficient spatial queries (ST_WITHIN and ST_DISTANCE).

trans-unit.source: Spatial indexes do not have a precision value, and always use a default precision value.
trans-unit.target: Spatial indexes do not have a precision value, and always use a default precision value.

trans-unit.source: The following JSON snippet shows an indexing policy with spatial indexing enabled, i.e. index any GeoJSON point found within documents for spatial querying.
trans-unit.target: The following JSON snippet shows an indexing policy with spatial indexing enabled, i.e. index any GeoJSON point found within documents for spatial querying.

trans-unit.source: If you are modifying the indexing policy using the Azure Preview Portal, you can specify the following JSON for indexing policy to enable spatial indexing on your collection.
trans-unit.target: If you are modifying the indexing policy using the Azure Preview Portal, you can specify the following JSON for indexing policy to enable spatial indexing on your collection.

trans-unit.source: Collection Indexing Policy JSON with Spatial enabled
trans-unit.target: Collection Indexing Policy JSON with Spatial enabled

trans-unit.source: Here's a code snippet in .NET that shows how to create a collection with spatial indexing turned on for all paths containing points.
trans-unit.target: Here's a code snippet in .NET that shows how to create a collection with spatial indexing turned on for all paths containing points.

trans-unit.source: Create a collection with spatial indexing
trans-unit.target: Create a collection with spatial indexing

trans-unit.source: And here's how you can modify an existing collection to take advantage of spatial indexing over any points that are stored within documents.
trans-unit.target: And here's how you can modify an existing collection to take advantage of spatial indexing over any points that are stored within documents.

trans-unit.source: Modify an existing collection with spatial indexing
trans-unit.target: Modify an existing collection with spatial indexing

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If the location GeoJSON value within the document is malformed or invalid, then it will not get indexed for spatial querying.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If the location GeoJSON value within the document is malformed or invalid, then it will not get indexed for spatial querying.

trans-unit.source: You can validate location values using ST_ISVALID and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED.
trans-unit.target: You can validate location values using ST_ISVALID and ST_ISVALIDDETAILED.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learnt about how to get started with geospatial support in DocumentDB, you can:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learnt about how to get started with geospatial support in DocumentDB, you can:

trans-unit.source: Start coding with the [Geospatial .NET code samples on Github](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/samples/code-samples/Queries.Spatial)
trans-unit.target: Start coding with the [Geospatial .NET code samples on Github](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/samples/code-samples/Queries.Spatial)

trans-unit.target: Get hands on with geospatial querying at the [DocumentDB Query Playground](http://www.documentdb.com/sql/demo#geospatial)

trans-unit.target: Learn more about [DocumentDB Query](documentdb-sql-query.md)

trans-unit.target: Learn more about [DocumentDB Indexing Policies](documentdb-indexing-policies.md)
